summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various officials (including SEC Chair Gary Gensler) alleging widespread SEC corruption, obstruction, and facilitation of securities fraud. Dilorio details specific cases involving companies like Global Tech Industries Group (GTII), Imaging Diagnostic Systems (IMDS), Cemtrex, FTE Networks, and Parallax Health Sciences, accusing the SEC of covering up illegal naked short selling, money laundering, and fraudulent schemes while denying his whistleblower awards. This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. DiIorio to various parties, including judges and the SEC, alleging massive, ongoing securities fraud, money laundering, and criminal obstruction by the SEC and related entities. It focuses on market manipulation, illegal naked short selling, and the SEC's failure to investigate companies like Riot Blockchain, Virtu Financial, and various penny stock shells.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, alleging massive SEC corruption, obstruction, and facilitation of securities fraud, money laundering, and illegal naked short selling across multiple companies.

persons.name: David Reichman
persons.context: Described as controlling money laundering shell companies like Global Tech Industries Group (GTII) and involved in fraudulent schemes over 17 years with no revenue.

persons.name: Calvin Cao
persons.context: CEO of We Supergreen, linked to previous money laundering shell Stem Cell Therapy, which had its registration revoked by the SEC.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Described as a 'Prolific Bag Man' involved in financing with Stem Cell Therapy and connected to other schemes like FreeSeas/TopShips.

persons.name: Linda Grable
persons.role: Former CEO of Imaging Diagnostic Systems
persons.context: Former CEO of IMDS, barred by the SEC, involved in executing a Share Purchase Agreement (SPA) with Viable International while the company's registration was being revoked.

persons.name: Alan Schwartz
persons.role: Former CFO of Imaging Diagnostic Systems
persons.context: Former CFO of IMDS, barred by the SEC, involved with Linda Grable in the Viable International SPA.

persons.name: Grable II
persons.context: Involved in executing the Viable International SPA for IMDS along with barred individuals Linda Grable and Alan Schwartz.

persons.name: Aron Govil
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for multi-million dollar fraud involving companies Cemtrex and Telidyne, accused of market manipulation and false claims.

persons.name: John M. Fife
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer; linked to companies like Iliad Research, St. George Investments, and FTE Networks.

persons.name: Alex Szkaradek
persons.context: CEO of Vision Property Management, sued by NY AG for predatory practices; involved in the sale of US Home Rentals to FTE Networks.

persons.name: Antoni Szkaradek
persons.context: Associated with Alex Szkaradek in Vision Property Management and the sale of US Home Rentals to FTE Networks.

persons.name: Michael Beys
persons.context: Interim CEO of FTE Networks, former EDNY prosecutor, involved in the company's transition to single-family home rentals.

persons.name: Paul Arena
persons.context: CEO of Parallax Health Sciences, charged by the SEC for misleading COVID-19 disclosures; previously involved with other shells like Augme and Geos Communications.

persons.name: Nathaniel Bradley
persons.context: Executive of Parallax Health Sciences, charged alongside Paul Arena for misleading COVID-19 disclosures.

persons.name: Ofer Abarbanel
persons.context: Subject of an SEC complaint for transferring approximately $102 million from investor funds into accounts of shell company NARL/State Fund.

persons.name: Nicholas Abbate
persons.role: COO of State Funds/New York Alaska
persons.context: COO of State Funds/New York Alaska (NARL), former independent market maker at Knight Capital; his company received $102 million in investor funds per the Abarbanel complaint.

persons.name: Gary Gensler
persons.context: Addressed in the emails by Dilorio regarding SEC corruption and inaction on alleged frauds.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: SEC New York official referenced in connection with the Cemtrex/Govil complaint, accused of omitting key details like money laundering.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: SEC New York official involved in the Cemtrex/Govil complaint, accused of intentional omissions.

persons.name: Kevin Goodman
persons.context: SEC official, later with FINRA oversight, involved in the Parallax COVID-19 disclosure complaint; accused of producing 'bullshit' complaints to cover up deeper issues.

persons.name: David Solomon
persons.context: Mentioned as current CEO of Goldman Sachs, connected to Milken obstruction of justice and associated with David 'djdsol' Solomon.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Described as a prolific 'Bag Man' linked to Russian entities, Signature Bank, and the law firm Sichenzia Ross; allegedly not out of business despite SEC actions.

persons.name: Christopher J. DiIorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to companies like Knight Capital, Virtu Financial, and Riot Blockchain.

persons.name: Chad Everett Harris
persons.context: Supervised the building of Whinstone's Rockdale, Texas data center in 2020; associated with Northern Data's acquisition and sale of Whinstone.

persons.name: Mathis Schultz
persons.context: Former private banker who founded Northern Data in 2015.

persons.name: Dougie Cifu
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Transparency'; accused of knowingly lying about Virtu Financial's equity market making share volumes on a May 2021 earnings call to conceal fraud.

persons.name: Alex Kramm
persons.context: Had an exchange with Dougie Cifu on the Q1 2021 earnings call; cited by DiIorio to challenge Cifu's transparency.

persons.name: Dan Fannon
persons.context: Addressed by Dougie Cifu on the Q1 2021 earnings call regarding share volumes.

persons.name: Ms. Pasquinelli
persons.context: Addressed in an email; part of the SEC staff alleged to be involved in corruption and expunging data from filings.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named in an SEC action (NewLead) based on DiIorio's information; associated with multiple money laundering shells and frauds.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.role: Accused Unregistered Penny Stock Dealer (JMJ Financial)
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for operating as an unregistered securities dealer; also known as JMJ Financial.

persons.name: Mr. Gottschall
persons.context: Allegedly conducted a superficial investigation into Riot Blockchain, ending it without visiting the company's HQ in Castle Rock, Colorado, facilitating ongoing fraud.

persons.name: Jeffrey McGonegal
persons.role: Chief Executive Officer of Riot Blockchain, Inc.
persons.context: Addressee of an SEC letter in December 2020 regarding a Riot Blockchain offering that was not reviewed due to Gottschall's prior investigation closure.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Ohio-based executive who paid to resolve False Claims Act allegations; became a large shareholder in Millennium Biotech (later Inergetics), which was controlled by Barry Honig.

persons.name: Chad Readler
persons.role: Former DOJ Prosecutor, now Federal Judge
persons.context: Was the prosecutor on Brian Colleran's civil healthcare fraud case; later made a federal judge by President Trump.

persons.name: Robert Eide
persons.context: CEO of Aegis Capital, implicated in SEC/FINRA actions; his pension plan was a seller in the SciSparc/Therapix offering.

persons.name: Kevin McKenna
persons.context: Named in FINRA/SEC actions related to Aegis Capital Corp for violations.

persons.name: Michael Bigger
persons.context: Described as a 'prolific Bag Man' involved with Aegis and related transactions.

persons.name: Dmitry Akhanov
persons.context: Russian official involved with Bioptix/Alphasniffer (later RIOT) and on the board of NeoPhotonics; raises national security concerns.

persons.name: Mark B Fisher
persons.role: Owner of MBF Clearing and MBF Capital
persons.context: New York-based financier whose entities were involved in a fraud 'acquisition' by Riot Blockchain; connections to Miami SEC Director Eric Bustilloe suggested.

persons.name: Eric Bustilloe
persons.context: Described as a 'grossly corrupt Piece of Shit' on par with Gottschall, implicated in obstruction related to Mark Fisher's Miami connections.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Sentenced by Judge Cote in a case DiIorio claims was a miscarriage of justice, set up by Handler/Ressler (Ares Management) for interfering with their deal.

persons.name: Judge Cote
persons.context: Sentenced Dan Kamensky; DiIorio argues she should have declared a mistrial due to corrupt relationships between the SEC and Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Implied to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC; involved in the situation leading to Dan Kamensky's sentencing.

persons.name: Ressler
persons.context: Drexel alumnus with Handler; Ares Management was involved in the Neiman Marcus deal that Kamensky interfered with.

persons.name: Jason Sunstein
persons.context: San Diego resident and CFO of several OTCM pink sheet companies (Viper Networks, Santeon Group, etc.), allegedly known to SEC LA officials.

persons.name: Ashraf Rofail
persons.role: CEO of Santeon Group/International Land Alliance
persons.context: CEO of companies involved in African/Egyptian entities and Mexico vacation property investments, using common stock as currency.

connections.description: Connected through the proposed merger of Reichman's GTII with Cao's We Supergreen, with Dilorio alleging the deal is a scam.
Both were barred former executives of IMDS who executed a Share Purchase Agreement with Viable International while the company was under SEC revocation.
Worked together on the Viable International SPA for IMDS, with Grable II claiming sole execution which Dilorio calls a lie.
Fife's entities (e.g., St. George Investments) provided convertible notes to FTE Networks, which Dilorio alleges were part of a money laundering scheme.
Szkaradek's Vision Property Management/US Home Rentals was acquired by FTE Networks in a $350 million deal involving stock and notes.
Govil was involved with Cemtrex, accused of fraud and market manipulation through paid buy recommendations.
Both SEC New York officials worked on the Cemtrex/Govil complaint, which Dilorio alleges intentionally omitted money laundering details.
Abarbanel transferred $102 million in investor funds to accounts of State Fund/NARL, where Abbate was COO.
Dilorio addresses Gensler directly in emails, urging action on SEC corruption and fraud allegations.
DiIorio accuses Cifu, CEO of Virtu Financial, of knowingly lying about share volumes to conceal massive illegal naked shorting and money laundering.
DiIorio directly attacks Gottschall for a corrupt and superficial SEC investigation into Riot Blockchain that facilitated ongoing fraud.
Both are implicated as 'prolific Bag Men' in multiple money laundering shell schemes, including Millennium/Inergetics and NewLead.
Both are involved in penny stock and money laundering schemes; Fife was involved with MGT Capital, a Honig shell, in 2019.
Honig's shell Bioptix (which pivoted to become RIOT) had Akhanov, a Russian official from Rusnano USA, as an insider, linking the scheme to Russian interests.
Both were involved with Aegis Capital Corp, which faced SEC/FINRA actions for violations; Eide was CEO, McKenna was associated.
DiIorio implies a corrupt connection between Fisher's Miami-based dealings and SEC Miami Director Eric Bustilloe, suggesting obstruction.
DiIorio claims Kamensky was set up by Handler (of Jefferies) and Ressler (of Ares) for interfering with their Neiman Marcus deal.
Readler was the DOJ prosecutor on Colleran's civil healthcare fraud case before becoming a judge appointed by Trump.

events.title: GTII and We Supergreen LOI
events.description: Global Tech Industries Group (GTII) signs a binding Letter of Intent to merge with We Supergreen, a deal Dilorio alleges is a scam.

events.title: IMDS-Viable International SPA
events.description: Imaging Diagnostic Systems (IMDS) executes a Share Purchase Agreement with Viable International, creating 37 billion shares that Dilorio alleges were unauthorized and used to cover naked short fails.

events.title: IMDS Reverse Stock Split
events.description: IMDS effects a 1:1000 reverse stock split, decreasing authorized shares from 40 billion to 500 million, which Dilorio ties to the cover-up of unauthorized share creation.

events.title: SEC Charges Against John Fife
events.description: SEC charges John M. Fife and his companies for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer.

events.title: FTE Acquires US Home Rentals
events.description: FTE Networks acquires US Home Rentals (Vision Property Management) from Alex and Antoni Szkaradek for $350 million in stock and notes.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Aron Govil
events.description: SEC files charges against Aron Govil for multi-million dollar fraud involving Cemtrex and Telidyne, including false claims about COVID-19 apps.

events.title: SEC Parallax COVID-19 Complaint
events.description: SEC charges Parallax Health Sciences and executives Paul Arena and Nathaniel Bradley for misleading COVID-19 disclosures.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch
events.description: Referenced as the 'August 2012 glitch' that Dilorio alleges was used by the SEC to bail out Knight Capital (NITE) from massive losses.

events.title: Virtu Financial Q1 2021 Earnings Call
events.description: CEO Dougie Cifu stated April volumes were 'a hair under 10 billion shares per day,' which DiIorio alleges is a blatant lie to conceal much higher volumes from illegal naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Ends Investigation into Riot Blockchain
events.description: SEC official Mr. Gottschall sent a letter ending the investigation into Riot Blockchain without recommending enforcement action, despite alleged fraud.

events.title: Northern Data Sells Whinstone Texas Data Center
events.description: Northern Data/Northern Bitcoin sold the Whinstone Texas data center, which had been supervised by Chad Everett Harris.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al. in Microcap Fraud
events.description: SEC filed charges against Joshua Sason and others in an elaborate microcap stock fraud case, which DiIorio claims was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges John M. Fife for Unregistered Dealing
events.description: SEC charged John M. Fife and his companies for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener (JMJ Financial)
events.description: SEC charged Justin Keener doing business as JMJ Financial for operating as an unregistered securities dealer.

events.title: SEC Non-Review of RIOT Offering
events.description: Following Gottschall's closed investigation, the SEC chose not to review a Riot Blockchain offering, leading to a Susquehanna/CVI pump and dump.

events.title: FINRA Settlement with Aegis Capital
events.description: FINRA accepted a settlement with Aegis Capital Corp and individuals including Robert Eide and Kevin McKenna for violations.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio alleges the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt, criminal organization' actively facilitating massive frauds, money laundering, and illegal naked short selling while obstructing his whistleblower claims.
Dilorio details specific schemes involving companies like GTII, IMDS, Cemtrex, FTE Networks, and Parallax, claiming they are money laundering shells with no legitimate revenue.

The document claims the SEC repeatedly bailed out Knight Capital (NITE) and other broker-dealers by covering up illegal naked short selling, including through the 2012 'glitch' and the IMDS-Viable International SPA.
Dilorio asserts that SEC complaints (e.g., against Cemtrex/Govil, FTE, Parallax) intentionally omit key details like money laundering to allow the schemes to continue.
The whistleblower states his information was used by the SEC for years, but the agency corruptly denied his award claims and obstructed investigations.

The whistleblower, Christopher J. DiIorio, alleges the SEC is engaged in massive, ongoing criminal obstruction and corruption, actively facilitating frauds on the public while denying him whistleblower awards.

Riot Blockchain (fka Aspen Bio, Venaxis, Bioptix) is alleged to be a Honig/Stetson money laundering shell with ties to Russian official Dmitry Akhanov of Rusnano USA, and its Colorado headquarters was never visited by the SEC during its investigation.

Virtu Financial (NITE) CEO Dougie Cifu is accused of knowingly lying about equity market making share volumes to conceal illegal naked shorting of OTC money laundering shells, which constitutes the core of its business.

Multiple SEC enforcement actions (against Joshua Sason, John Fife, Justin Keener) are claimed to be based on DiIorio's information but were not posted to the SEC Whistleblower Award Eligible website, indicating obstruction.

The document alleges deep interconnectedness between various fraudsters (Honig, Sason, Fife), corrupt SEC officials (Gottschall, Bustilloe, Pasquinelli), and entities like Aegis Capital, Signature Bank (SBNY), and Sichenzia Ross law firm.
